title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement layal.lettry@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to rrclust
text: outlines propose change rrclust. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to rrclust
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to rrclust
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to rrclust
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("asam-group/rrclust", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to rrclust
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept. use SNAKE_CASE specify tidy data frame snake_case vectors.

title: Contributing to rrclust
text: Please note rrclust project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Authors and Citation
Authors and Citation
text: Lettry LC (2023). rrclust: Clustering Swiss Pension Register. https://github.com/asam-group/rrclust, https://asam-group.github.io/rrclust/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {rrclust: Clustering the Swiss Pension Register},   author = {Layal Christine Lettry},   year = {2023},   note = {https://github.com/asam-group/rrclust, https://asam-group.github.io/rrclust/}, }

title: Clustering the Swiss Pension Register
text: goal rrclust cluster Swiss Pension Register (CCO/FSIO) using kamila R package. anonymous data Swiss Pension Register (CCO/FSIO) typically used estimate project (short, middle long term) revenues expenditures Old-Age Survivors’ Insurance (OASI). perspective, essential clear look register’s main statistical features. better understand benefit richness, propose analysing raw data appropriate clustering method. face three main difficulties: continuous also nominal categorical variables structure register, choose clustering method considers types variables; priori number clusters first step determined, thus question fix essential; method run big data. Recently, . Foss et al. (2016) . H. Foss Markatou (2018) proposed kamila Method (KAy-means MIxed LArge data), specifically designed manage clustering process mixed distributions. Furthermore, simple rewriting kamila’s algorithm permits easy implementation map-reduce framework like Hadoop, thus run large data sets. hand, Tibshirani Walther (2005) advocate use “Prediction Strength” measure find optimal number clusters. applied kamila clustering method 2 000 000 observations Swiss Pension Register (CCO/FSIO) data. technique allows us determine optimal number clusters. basis, can analyse partition data. Indeed, cluster analysed, principal features described. result, becomes possible recognise similarities dissimilarities OASI pensioners subgroups according socio-demographic characteristics. pieces information crucial predicting revenues expenditures OASI.

title: Clustering the Swiss Pension Register
text: next step implement classification methods package rrml applied kamila-clustered Swiss Pension Register (CCO/FSIO) thanks package rrclust.

title: Clustering the Swiss Pension Register
text: global workflow rrclust package depicted figure shown . green ellipses correspond modules defined functions accepting certain class inputs, namely tibbles. tibbles can enter modules individually form lists tibbles, namely tidylists, containing tibbles tidy form needed modules. red rectangles give name tibbles either inputs outputs modules. Therefore, outputs transformation initial tibbles. blue rectangles depict top level outputs, LOG indicating run log including rrclust package version, dplyr library version, date time code execution. arrows indicate direction process. two arrows ellipse rectangle directions, means input renamed especially module given back output. case FULL_CONT_DF FULL_CATEG_DF renamed tibbles resp. CONT_DF CATEG_DF contains outcome variables aadr monthly_pension opposite siblings.

title: Clustering the Swiss Pension Register
text: Since Swiss Pension Register (CCO/FSIO) data public, offer two examples randomly generated data used demonstrate workflow package.

what: Example step by step with randomly generated data
title: Clustering the Swiss Pension Register
code: # enumerate required packages and test if they are installed required_pkgs <- c(   "data.table", "DiagrammeRsvg", "dplyr", "fs", "magick", "memoise",   "rlang", "rrclust", "rstudioapi", "rsvg", "shiny", "tidyr", "utils" ) for (pkg in required_pkgs) {   requireNamespace(pkg) }  # load rrclust library(rrclust)  # directory for the output path_out <- tempdir()  # generate random demo data path_random_data <- gen_demo_data()  # read the demo data demo_data <- tidylist_read(path_random_data)  # relative path to the params container path <- file.path(getwd(), "inst", "extdata", "params_kamila_large")  # read PARAM_GLOBAL tl_PARAM_GLOBAL <- param_tidylist_read(path)  # replace empty variable with the temporary path tl_PARAM_GLOBAL$PARAM_GLOBAL[["path_data"]] <- stringr::str_remove(   dirname(path_random_data), "/all" ) PARAM_GLOBAL <- tl_PARAM_GLOBAL$PARAM_GLOBAL |>   dplyr::mutate_all(as.character) |>   tidyr::pivot_longer(     everything(),     names_to = "key",     values_to = "value"   )  # rewrite PARAM_GLOBAL with the demo data path tidylist_write(tidylist(PARAM_GLOBAL), path = path)  # input tl_inp_kamila <- mod_inp_kamila(path = path, method_name = "kamila")  # computations tl_out_kamila <- wrap_kamila(tl_inp_kamila = tl_inp_kamila)  # output path_out_identifier <- mod_out_kamila(   path = path,   path_out = path_out,   tl_inp_kamila = tl_inp_kamila,   tl_out_kamila = tl_out_kamila )  # write the csv files tidylist_write(   c(tl_out_kamila, mod_log()),   path_out_identifier )  # store parameters (as a reference) copy_param(path, path_out_identifier)  # access the output browseURL(path_out_identifier)

what: Example in one step with randomly generated data
title: Clustering the Swiss Pension Register
code: # enumerate required packages and test if they are installed required_pkgs <- c(   "data.table", "DiagrammeRsvg", "dplyr", "fs", "magick", "memoise",   "rlang", "rrclust", "rstudioapi", "rsvg", "shiny", "tidyr", "utils" ) for (pkg in required_pkgs) {   requireNamespace(pkg) }  # load rrclust library(rrclust)  # directory for the output path_out <- tempdir()  # generate random demo data path_random_data <- gen_demo_data()  # read the demo data demo_data <- tidylist_read(path_random_data)  # relative path to the params container path <- file.path(getwd(), "inst", "extdata", "params_kamila_large")  # read PARAM_GLOBAL tl_PARAM_GLOBAL <- param_tidylist_read(path)  # replace empty variable with the temporary path tl_PARAM_GLOBAL$PARAM_GLOBAL[["path_data"]] <- stringr::str_remove(   dirname(path_random_data), "/all" ) PARAM_GLOBAL <- tl_PARAM_GLOBAL$PARAM_GLOBAL |>   dplyr::mutate_all(as.character) |>   tidyr::pivot_longer(     everything(),     names_to = "key",     values_to = "value"   )  # rewrite PARAM_GLOBAL with the demo data path tidylist_write(tidylist(PARAM_GLOBAL), path = path)  # execute the whole workflow rrclust::run_kamila(path = path, path_out = path_out)  # access the output browseURL(path_out)

title: Clustering the Swiss Pension Register
text: can see results CSV file named KM_RES_FINAL.csv. best number clusters, .e. parameter kstar, given value variable num_clust. CSV file KM_RES.csv shows prediction strengths values number clusters ran program (see parameter numberofclusters PARAM_KAMILA.csv) iteration.

what: Splitting the initial dataset into kstar clusters — mod_calc_kamila
title: Splitting the initial dataset into kstar clusters — mod_calc_kamila
text: Splitting initial dataset kstar clusters using parameter kstar determined module mod_kstar.

title: Splitting the initial dataset into kstar clusters — mod_calc_kamila
code: mod_calc_kamila(   PARAM_KAMILA,   CONT_DF,   CATEG_DF,   FULL_CONT_DF,   FULL_CATEG_DF,   KM_RES,   list = NULL )

title: Splitting the initial dataset into kstar clusters — mod_calc_kamila
text: PARAM_KAMILA data frame needed parameters Kamila method, following parameters used: - numinit: number initializations used. - maxiter: maximum number iterations run. - param_kstar: Best number clusters estimated module mod_kstar. CONT_DF Subset pension register containing continuous variables except outcome variables aadr monthly_pension. CATEG_DF Subset pension register containing categorical variables factors except nominal variables marital_stat benef_type. FULL_CONT_DF Data frame containing continuous variables used estimation plus outcome variables aadr monthly_pension. FULL_CATEG_DF Data frame containing categorical variables used estimation plus nominal variables marital_stat benef_type. KM_RES Tibble contains kamila results training set. list List input data frames.

title: Splitting the initial dataset into kstar clusters — mod_calc_kamila
text: tidylist containing following tidy data frames: PLOTDATKAM Data frame containing clusters factor variables. KM_RES_FINAL Data frame containing resulting parameters clustering. CONTVARS Data frame containing continuous standardised variables. FULL_CONT_DF Data frame containing continuous variables used estimation. FULL_CATEG_DF Data frame containing categorical variables used estimation.

title: Splitting the initial dataset into kstar clusters — mod_calc_kamila

what: Splitting the continuous from the categorical data — mod_catcontvar
title: Splitting the continuous from the categorical data — mod_catcontvar
text: Splits continuous categorical data, order use clustering method.

title: Splitting the continuous from the categorical data — mod_catcontvar
code: mod_catcontvar(RR_OASI, RR_OASI_TS, RR_OASI_VS, PARAM_GLOBAL, list = NULL)

title: Splitting the continuous from the categorical data — mod_catcontvar
text: RR_OASI data frame containing OASI data, whose variables : year: Year pension register extract. age: Age individual. age_retire: Effective retirement age. sex: Sex, female female, 0 male. nat: Nationality, foreign 1, 0 Swiss. resid: Residence, foreign 1, 0 Swiss. benef_type1: Old-age type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type2: Widow type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type3: Father's orphan type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type4: Mother's orphan type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type5: Twice orphan type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type6: Spouse's compl. type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type7: Father's child rent type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type8: Mother's child rent type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type : Types benefits type benefit (categorical). marital_stat1: Divorced marital status 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). marital_stat2: Single reference category marital status 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). marital_stat3: Married marital status 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). marital_stat4: Widowed marital status 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). marital_stat: Marital status. splitting: 1, splitting revenues, 0 otherwise. capping:  1, pension capped, 0 otherwise. contrib_m_ind: Total number OASI contribution months per individual. contrib_y_ageclass: Total number contribution years per age group. bonus_m_edu: Number months paid bonus educative tasks. bonus_m_assist: Number months paid bonus assistance/care tasks. RR_OASI_TS Training set containing x% data. RR_OASI_VS Validation set containing (100 - x)% data. PARAM_GLOBAL Data frame containing parameters. use following: categ_var: Set chosen categorical variables. cont_var: Set chosen continuous variables. list List input data frames.

title: Splitting the continuous from the categorical data — mod_catcontvar
text: tidylist containing following tidy data frames: CATEG_DF: Contains categorical variables (factors). CONT_DF : Contains continuous variables (numeric). CATEG_DF_TS: Contains categorical variables (factors), training set. CONT_DF_TS : Contains continuous variables (numeric), training set. CATEG_DF_VS: Contains categorical variables (factors), validation set. CONT_DF_VS : Contains continuous variables (numeric), validation set.

title: Splitting the continuous from the categorical data — mod_catcontvar
Splitting the continuous from the categorical data — mod_catcontvar
Splitting the continuous from the categorical data — mod_catcontvar
code: #' @examples #' # create random data #' IND_YEARLY_RR <- structure( #'   list( #'     alt = c( #'       46L, 38L, 14L, 75L, 30L #'     ), #'     sex = c( #'       "f", "f", "f", "f", "m" #'     ), #'     nat = c( #'       "ch", "ch", "ch", "au", "ch" #'     ), #'     dom = c( #'       "ch", "au", "ch", "ch", "ch" #'     ), #'     gpr = c( #'       "rveuve", "renfant_pere_simple", #'       "rorphelin_pere_simple", "rvieillesse_simple", "renfant_pere_simple" #'     ), #'     zv = c( #'       "geschieden", "geschieden", "ledig", "ledig", "geschieden" #'     ), #'     csplit = c(NA, NA, NA, 0L, NA), #'     cplaf = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 0L, #'       NA #'     ), jahr = c(2023L, 2023L, 2023L, 2023L, 2023L), #'     ram = c( #'       879274L, 2988594L, 5111279L, 8900743L, 1322875L #'     ), #'     monatliche_rente = c( #'       3399L, 2298L, 541L, 2496L, 3894L #'     ), #'     age_ret = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 68L, NA #'     ), #'     eprc = c( #'       0.0526315789473684, 0.0294117647058824, 0.024390243902439, 0.1, 0.125 #'     ), #'     lcot = c( #'       7L, 494L, 209L, 128L, 323L #'     ), #'     lcotg = c( #'       38L, #'       22L, 13L, 20L, 44L #'     ), #'     lbedu = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 394L, NA #'     ), #'     lbass = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 333L, NA #'     ) #'   ), #'   class = c("tbl_df", "tbl", "data.frame"), #'   row.names = c(NA, -5L) #' ) #' # create RR_OASI #' tl_mod_prepa_rr <- mod_prepa_rr(IND_YEARLY_RR = IND_YEARLY_RR) #' #' # create PARAM_GLOBAL #' PARAM_GLOBAL_TIDY <- structure( #'   list( #'     key = c( #'       "method_name", #'       "path_data", #'       "description", #'       "pct_sample_ts", #'       "categ_var", #'       "cont_var" #'     ), #'     value = c( #'       "kamila", #'       "", #'       "Kamila method", #'       "80", #'       "sex, nat, resid, benef_type1, benef_type2, benef_type3, benef_type4, #'        benef_type5, #'    benef_type6, benef_type7, benef_type8, benef_type, marital_stat1, #'    marital_stat2, #'    marital_stat3, marital_stat4, marital_stat, splitting, capping", #'       "year, aadr, monthly_pension, age, age_retire, scale, contrib_m_ind, #'    contrib_y_ageclass, bonus_m_edu, bonus_m_assist" #'     ) #'   ), #'   class = c("tbl_df", "tbl", "data.frame"), #'   row.names = c( #'     NA, #'     -6L #'   ) #' ) #' #' # spread PARAM_GLOBAL_TIB #' read_param_tib <- function(tib) { #'   z1 <- tidyr::pivot_wider(tib, names_from = key, values_from = value) #'   if (identical(dim(z1), c(0L, 0L))) { #'     return(z1) #'   } #'   select(z1, one_of(tib[["key"]])) #' } #' #' PARAM_GLOBAL <- read_param_tib(PARAM_GLOBAL_TIDY) |> #'   mutate(pct_sample_ts = as.numeric(pct_sample_ts)) #' #' # Splitting the data into a Training and a Validation sets #' tl_mod_tsvs <- mod_tsvs( #'   RR_OASI = tl_mod_prepa_rr$RR_OASI, #'   PARAM_GLOBAL = PARAM_GLOBAL #' ) #' #' mod_catcontvar( #'   RR_OASI = tl_mod_prepa_rr$RR_OASI, #'   RR_OASI_TS = tl_mod_tsvs$RR_OASI_TS, #'   RR_OASI_VS = tl_mod_tsvs$RR_OASI_VS, #'   PARAM_GLOBAL = PARAM_GLOBAL #' )

what: Estimation of the best number of clusters using the Kamila algorithm — mod_kstar
title: Estimation of the best number of clusters using the Kamila algorithm — mod_kstar
text: Estimation best number clusters using Kamila algorithm training set.

title: Estimation of the best number of clusters using the Kamila algorithm — mod_kstar
Estimation of the best number of clusters using the Kamila algorithm — mod_kstar
text: PARAM_KAMILA data frame needed parameters Kamila method, following parameters used: numberofclusters: number clusters returned algorithm, .e. sequence indicating number clusters investigated extract optimal number clusters. numinit: number initializations used. maxiter: maximum number iterations run. calcnumclust: Character: Method selecting number clusters. Setting calcNumClust ’ps’ uses prediction strength method Tibshirani &Walther (J. Comp. Graphical Stats. 14(3), 2005). pred_threshold: Threshold fixed 0.8 well separated clusters, .e. overlapping. CATEG_DF_TS Training set pension register containing categorical variables factors. CONT_DF_TS Training set pension register containing continuous variables. list List input data frames.

title: Estimation of the best number of clusters using the Kamila algorithm — mod_kstar
text: tidylist containing following tidy data frames: KM_RES Data frame containing results clustering. PARAM_KAMILA Data frame updated kstar parameter.

title: Estimation of the best number of clusters using the Kamila algorithm — mod_kstar

what: Prepare the pension register data — mod_prepa_rr
title: Prepare the pension register data — mod_prepa_rr
Prepare the pension register data — mod_prepa_rr
Prepare the pension register data — mod_prepa_rr
text: IND_YEARLY_RR data frame containing data pension register subsetted one year . list List input data frames.

title: Prepare the pension register data — mod_prepa_rr
text: tidylist containing following tidy data frames: RR_OASI : data frame containing OASI data, whose variables : variables: year: Year pension register extract. age: Age individual. age_retire: Effective retirement age. sex: Sex, female female, 0 male. nat: Nationality, foreign 1, 0 Swiss. resid: Residence, foreign 1, 0 Swiss. benef_type1: Old-age type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type2: Widow type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type3: Father's orphan type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type4: Mother's orphan type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type5: Twice orphan type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type6: Spouse's compl. type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type7: Father's child rent type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type8: Mother's child rent type benefit 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). benef_type : Types benefits type benefit (categorical). marital_stat1: Divorced marital status 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). marital_stat2: Single reference category marital status 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). marital_stat3: Married marital status 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). marital_stat4: Widowed marital status 1, 0 otherwise (dummy). marital_stat: Marital status. splitting: 1, splitting revenues, 0 otherwise. capping:  1, pension capped, 0 otherwise. contrib_m_ind: Total number OASI contribution months per individual. contrib_y_ageclass: Total number contribution years per age group. bonus_m_edu: Number months paid bonus educative tasks. bonus_m_assist: Number months paid bonus assistance/care tasks.

title: Prepare the pension register data — mod_prepa_rr
Prepare the pension register data — mod_prepa_rr
code: #' @examples #' IND_YEARLY_RR <- structure( #'   list( #'     alt = c( #'       46L, 38L, 14L, 75L, 30L #'     ), #'     sex = c( #'       "f", "f", "f", "f", "m" #'     ), #'     nat = c( #'       "ch", "ch", "ch", "au", "ch" #'     ), #'     dom = c( #'       "ch", "au", "ch", "ch", "ch" #'     ), #'     gpr = c( #'       "rveuve", "renfant_pere_simple", #'       "rorphelin_pere_simple", "rvieillesse_simple", "renfant_pere_simple" #'     ), #'     zv = c( #'       "geschieden", "geschieden", "ledig", "ledig", "geschieden" #'     ), #'     csplit = c(NA, NA, NA, 0L, NA), #'     cplaf = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 0L, #'       NA #'     ), jahr = c(2023L, 2023L, 2023L, 2023L, 2023L), #'     ram = c( #'       879274L, 2988594L, 5111279L, 8900743L, 1322875L #'     ), #'     monatliche_rente = c( #'       3399L, 2298L, 541L, 2496L, 3894L #'     ), #'     age_ret = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 68L, NA #'     ), #'     eprc = c( #'       0.0526315789473684, 0.0294117647058824, 0.024390243902439, 0.1, 0.125 #'     ), #'     lcot = c( #'       7L, 494L, 209L, 128L, 323L #'     ), #'     lcotg = c( #'       38L, #'       22L, 13L, 20L, 44L #'     ), #'     lbedu = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 394L, NA #'     ), #'     lbass = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 333L, NA #'     ) #'   ), #'   class = c("tbl_df", "tbl", "data.frame"), #'   row.names = c(NA, -5L) #' ) #' #' mod_prepa_rr(IND_YEARLY_RR = IND_YEARLY_RR)

what: Split the data into a Training set and a Validation set — mod_tsvs
title: Split the data into a Training set and a Validation set — mod_tsvs
text: Split data training validation sets, givenvthe large number observations, order determine best number clusters KAMILA algorithm.

title: Split the data into a Training set and a Validation set — mod_tsvs
Split the data into a Training set and a Validation set — mod_tsvs
text: RR_OASI data frame containing data. PARAM_GLOBAL data frame containing parameters. use following parameter: pct_sample_ts: percentage observations build training set. list List input data frames.

title: Split the data into a Training set and a Validation set — mod_tsvs
text: tidylist containing following tidy data frames: RR_OASI_TS : Training set categorical data. RR_OASI_VS: Validation set categorical data.

title: Split the data into a Training set and a Validation set — mod_tsvs
Split the data into a Training set and a Validation set — mod_tsvs
Split the data into a Training set and a Validation set — mod_tsvs
code: #' @examples #' # create random data #' IND_YEARLY_RR <- structure( #'   list( #'     alt = c( #'       46L, 38L, 14L, 75L, 30L #'     ), #'     sex = c( #'       "f", "f", "f", "f", "m" #'     ), #'     nat = c( #'       "ch", "ch", "ch", "au", "ch" #'     ), #'     dom = c( #'       "ch", "au", "ch", "ch", "ch" #'     ), #'     gpr = c( #'       "rveuve", "renfant_pere_simple", #'       "rorphelin_pere_simple", "rvieillesse_simple", "renfant_pere_simple" #'     ), #'     zv = c( #'       "geschieden", "geschieden", "ledig", "ledig", "geschieden" #'     ), #'     csplit = c(NA, NA, NA, 0L, NA), #'     cplaf = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 0L, #'       NA #'     ), jahr = c(2023L, 2023L, 2023L, 2023L, 2023L), #'     ram = c( #'       879274L, 2988594L, 5111279L, 8900743L, 1322875L #'     ), #'     monatliche_rente = c( #'       3399L, 2298L, 541L, 2496L, 3894L #'     ), #'     age_ret = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 68L, NA #'     ), #'     eprc = c( #'       0.0526315789473684, 0.0294117647058824, 0.024390243902439, 0.1, 0.125 #'     ), #'     lcot = c( #'       7L, 494L, 209L, 128L, 323L #'     ), #'     lcotg = c( #'       38L, #'       22L, 13L, 20L, 44L #'     ), #'     lbedu = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 394L, NA #'     ), #'     lbass = c( #'       NA, NA, NA, 333L, NA #'     ) #'   ), #'   class = c("tbl_df", "tbl", "data.frame"), #'   row.names = c(NA, -5L) #' ) #' # create RR_OASI #' tl_mod_prepa_rr <- mod_prepa_rr(IND_YEARLY_RR = IND_YEARLY_RR) #' #' # create PARAM_GLOBAL #' PARAM_GLOBAL_TIDY <- structure( #'   list( #'     key = c( #'       "method_name", #'       "path_data", #'       "description", #'       "pct_sample_ts", #'       "categ_var", #'       "cont_var" #'     ), #'     value = c( #'       "kamila", #'       "", #'       "Kamila method", #'       "80", #'       "sex, nat, resid, benef_type1, benef_type2, benef_type3, benef_type4, #'       benef_type5, #'   benef_type6, benef_type7, benef_type8, benef_type, marital_stat1, #'   marital_stat2, #'   marital_stat3, marital_stat4, marital_stat, splitting, capping", #'       "year, aadr, monthly_pension, age, age_retire, scale, contrib_m_ind, #'   contrib_y_ageclass, bonus_m_edu, bonus_m_assist" #'     ) #'   ), #'   class = c("tbl_df", "tbl", "data.frame"), #'   row.names = c( #'     NA, #'     -6L #'   ) #' ) #' # spread PARAM_GLOBAL_TIB #' read_param_tib <- function(tib) { #'   z1 <- tidyr::pivot_wider(tib, names_from = key, values_from = value) #' #'   if (identical(dim(z1), c(0L, 0L))) { #'     return(z1) #'   } #' #'   select(z1, one_of(tib[["key"]])) #' } #' PARAM_GLOBAL <- read_param_tib(PARAM_GLOBAL_TIDY) |> #'   mutate(pct_sample_ts = as.numeric(pct_sample_ts)) #' #' # Splitting the data into a Training and a Validation sets #' tl_mod_tsvs <- mod_tsvs( #'   RR_OASI = tl_mod_prepa_rr$RR_OASI, #'   PARAM_GLOBAL = PARAM_GLOBAL #' )
